slidelink.displaytext: Protocol for the Standard Setting Process
Clearly Describe the Standard Setting Procedure

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Welcome to Measuring Student Growth: A Practical Guide to Educator Evaluation.  These modules are the result of a collaborative effort involving many educators from across Wayne County, Michigan. These educators were dedicated to identifying fair, transparent, and appropriate methods for measuring student growth throughout the educator evaluation process.  Teachers, administrators, central office leaders, and ISD staff worked together to understand the research related to student growth models and the best ways with which to implement these models in today’s educational environment.

The guidance found within these modules represents more than a year and a half of study, analysis, debate, and thoughtful reflection.

This module will cover the content from section 4 of the Student Growth document.

For more information and resources please visit the Educator Evaluation section of RESA’s website.

How much growth is enough?

This question is troublesome to educators when considering how to incorporate student growth measurement into educator evaluation.

This module will provide an overview of the standard setting process as one method of setting the cut score or criteria for student growth.

The information provided in this modules is based on the Wayne RESA document, Measuring Student Growth: A Practical Guide to Educator Evaluation.

Upon completing this module,

• The participant will have a general understanding of the standard setting process.

• The participant will also be familiar with the content that is covered in Chapter 4.

And,

• The participant will consider how to implement this process.

Throughout this module, you will have the option to pause to consider the connection between the information in this module with your own experiences and ideas about working with student growth data that comes from your current practice in your school or district.

Please take a moment to consider:

How much growth is enough?

You are encouraged to use the Google Doc, linked on this slide, to record your thoughts for later reference and reelection as your understanding of student growth evolves. You will need to “Make A Copy” of this document before you are able to add your ideas. https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uPD9y65feg7BD4JU153PFGGHO7bBylheiUk48TX1fZY/edit?usp=sharing

What is Standard Setting in Student Growth Measurement for Educator Evaluation?

Standard setting is a process involving professionals, for defining cut scores, that is based on local school district achievement data.

The standard setting process is used to find the cut scores for student growth

The purpose of the cut score is to indicate the threshold for each teacher evaluation category – Highly Effective, Effective, Minimally Effective, and Ineffective.

The standard setting process can be used with any growth model.

Think about it this way:

The assessment you use for student growth is the tool for collecting data about the student achievement.

The growth model is the method that is used to compare the students’ performance at two points in time.

The Standard Setting process is the process that is used to involve stakeholders in determining how much growth is enough, or in other words, the criteria that will be used to make judgements about the growth of students.

There are a variety of data types that may be used with the standard setting process. This table summarizes the range of data types that may be available for measuring student growth, depending on the grade, content area, and district assessment plan. Typical data types include state assessment data, district assessments (that may be purchased or locally developed), classroom assessments, and collections of evidence, such as IEPs, portfolios, or student capstone experiences.

The standard setting process can be used with any type of assessment.

Data is only meaningful when considered in a context that addresses factors that can impact the data in positive and negative ways. Here are some things to consider when identifying and working with your data types for student growth measurement.

q Who are the students who are included and excluded?

q What special factors do we need to consider?

q What may have occurred that negatively impacted student growth?

q Did the teachers have a sufficient instructional interval to demonstrate growth?

q What standard(s) are the being measured?

q Will the growth measurement data be weighted by other factors? How?

This is a sample form that you may use to summarize the assessments available to be used in your student growth data review.

Click on the image above to open this form within Google Docs. https://docs.google.com/document/d/1IuoROp74rsQifRLiT3s9NIhZgTAnwFl8nNt01rITxLU/edit?usp=sharing

Please take a moment to reflect on this information relative to your experiences and ideas about student growth data.

• Have you identified the data sources that you will be using for growth measurement?

• What are the factors in your school that will impact student growth measures?

Record your thoughts for as a record of your questions, learning and, perhaps, new ideas.

Use a standard protocol for the standard setting process.

These clearly defined steps will help you to manage the data, arrangements, and discussions to arrive at meaningful consensus on your growth criteria.

Step 1: Assemble a team of professionals who will be able to represent the content knowledge, understand the data, and work well on the team. Make sure you have someone who is good at making data displays and communicating the data. You will also need to identify a good team facilitator.

Step 2: Document your process. Write out your norms, meeting dates, meeting agendas and directions for how this is going to work so that your process is documented and defensible if challenged later.

Step 3. Establish the data sources for student growth – Identify the data you will use for growth measurement and summarize it so that it can be reviewed on the team. At this step you will need to establish business rules for managing missing data, attendance issues, and other considerations.

Step 4. Clarify your growth assumptions. Identify your growth model and clarify assumptions about growth for students who are not proficient on state standards.

Step 5. Write performance level descriptors. Write down the criteria for your expectations of what student growth looks like and means for the Effectiveness categories with out using numbers. These descriptions will serve as the criteria for setting your cut scores when the team reviews the data.

Step 6. Train the committee members who will be doing the standard setting process. Make sure they understand the data and that you are clear about their job. This is important to keep the meetings efficient and on-task.

Step 7. Implement the standard setting procedure. Have the meeting and work through the data with the committee to arrive at consensus for your criteria.

Step 8. Evaluate the process. When the work is done, as the committee members to provide feedback. Did the process work?

Step 9. Share the recommendations. It will be important to summarize the work of the committee and report out the recommendations to the larger school community so that the criteria can be understood and implemented.

Please take a moment to reflect on this information relative to your experiences and ideas about student growth data.

What might be the benefits to bringing your team together to engage in this process?

What are your challenges to involving stakeholders in setting district criteria?

Record your thoughts for as a record of your questions, learning and, perhaps, new ideas.

We will move forward focusing on some important details when planning to implement a standard setting process.

As mentioned earlier, it will be important to establish business rules for standard setting.

These rules will support you to be using data that are comparable and consistent.

Business rules should address such issues as

Student Attendance Rates

Classroom Enrollments and changes to enrollments

Demographics

Missing Data

And Extenuating circumstances

Take the time to work out these details before bringing in the committee to set the growth criteria.

As part of setting up the standard setting, make sure you are very clear with participants about their tasks. Do not let the conversations stray to personal agendas.

The participant tasks are clearly listed.

1. Review and learn how to read the growth data

2. Review and clarify your understanding of the performance level descriptor categories. The performance level descriptors are the criteria for defining cut scores. If you fail

use the criteria, your judgements will have personal bias that is not helpful to the consensus process.

3. Each participant must first independently rate the data points that best match the performance level descriptors. There should be no cross talk when reviewing the data.

4. Once the data are summarized, review how your decisions compare to the rest of the team. Review this feedback and impact data.

5. The process of reviewing data may be repeated until the committee reaches consensus.

6. It is an expectation that each participant contributes to the final recommendations.

7. When asked to provide feedback on the process, be constructive and honest in your rating of the experience and outcomes.

Earlier we mentioned the Performance Level Descriptors.

Here is an example of what this criteria looks like. You may word your criteria to fit your data type and the expectations of growth that are meaningful in your context.

In this example, effective growth is defined as

Master of SEVERAL grade level standards at grade expectancy as measured by the local benchmark assessment.

The other effectiveness categories tend to differentiated by the range, pattern, degree, duration, or quality of student performance.

Note - do not use numbers such as percent, percentiles, standard scores to describe your criteria. If you interject number in the criteria then you do not need to use the standard setting process as you already defined cut scores in your criteria.

The purpose of the standard setting process is to find the meaningful cut scores.

Here is another example of a performance level descriptor.

In this example, the district is using simple gain scores to determine student growth. A Gain Score is the difference between a pre test and a post test.

These criteria define effective growth as gains in scores that are consistent with patterns representing the majority of gain scores.

Again, note that the criteria is defining growth in terms of range, pattern, degree, duration, or quality of student performance.

Practice developing a performance level descriptor for your assessments.

Here are some steps to help you develop your criteria.

1. Establish your categories, e.g., Highly Effective, Effective, Minimally Effective

2. Consider a data source in your district.

3. Write a description of the growth performance that best characterizes the category. It helps to start with the line between EFFECTIVE and MINIMALLY EFFECTIVE performance.

4. Do NOT reference data points – Use descriptive terms such as pattern, mastery, range, duration, degree or quality.

Once you have your performance level descriptor data, you will use the criteria to gauge the cut score.

Think about standard setting as starting at the middle and moving a gauge up or down to match the criteria of the performance level descriptors.

You will need to guide the participants to work with the data by,

First, Locating the midpoint in the data

Then, Asking themselves: Does this data point meet the performance level description that distinguishes effective from minimally effective?

The participant will then adjust the data point up or down until the best data point representation is achieved in their judgement.

Each participant must do this independently before reviewing their thinking together to reach consensus.
Here is a sample form for summarizing the ratings of the participants on the standard setting committee.

Here are some tips for the facilitator of the standard setting process.

It can be difficult to manage groups and difficult discussions. Keep these questions in mind and hold to them to guide the group to reaching consensus.

The key discussion questions are listed:

Describe what you see when you review these data?

What stands out to you?

Are the scores representative of the Performance Level Descriptors?

Does the impact match your judgement of what is realistic?

Is this fair to teachers and students?

Consider this image: https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/image-three-business-partners-discussing-documents-134719040?src=6eLqQp5T-QbabJngn6smNQ-1-15

Consider this image: https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/image-three-business-partners-discussing-documents-134719040?src=6eLqQp5T-QbabJngn6smNQ-1-15

Once the committee arrives at consensus the data will need to be summarized.

In this example, the cut scores for each category have been identified by the standard setting process.

The data show the impact based on the percent of students whose scores would be in each category.

Another way to look at impact would be to examine the number or percent of teachers who would be rated as Minimally Effective, Effective, or Highly Effective using these cut scores.

This information can then be used to create rubrics for your growth measurement.

It is important to evaluate the process with your committee participants.

The key questions to ask are:

Was this reasonable? – Did the process set reasonable expectations on you are a participant?

Can this be replicated? – If another panel were assembled with the same criteria and data, would they reach similar recommendations?

Is this fair? – Was the process fair to the participants in the activities and time allocated? Will the recommendations that come from this process be fair to educators when implemented?

• It will be important to summarize the recommendations of the standard setting process.

• Make sure to report on the criteria of the performance level descriptors, the data used, and the recommendations of the team. Make sure to include information that describes the process.

• You will need to explain the data that was used for the standard setting process and the information that was used to investigate the impact of the cut scores on educators who will be evaluated based on this standard.

• The report must provide a format, such as a rubric that defines the cut scores and how they are to be applied in the educator evaluation process.

• Be aware of revisions that may arise from the state and incorporate any anticipated changes to your criteria.

• Include recommendations for future review committees and timelines for evaluating how well the cut scores are working.

This concludes the module that provides an overview of the standard setting process.

Take a moment to consider how this process would work in your setting. Evaluate how this process might work for you and discuss with your colleagues.

• Is this process reasonable?

• Is this a process you might replicate?

• Is this process fair to educators and students?

For more information regarding Understanding Student Growth and Educator Evaluation, we encourage you to visit the Educator Evaluation section of Wayne RESA’s website at http://www.resa.net/curriculum/educator-evaluation/

Here you will find a variety of resources including this module, a downloadable version of the guidance document entitled “Understanding Student Growth: A Practical Guide To Educator Evaluation” as well as the online modules designed to assist learners as they delve deeper into the content of this manual.
